head.title: The Way We Live Now Poll

hedline.hl1: The Way We Live Now Poll

abstract.p: Gestalt Center for Psychotherapy and Training executive director Vivien D Wolsk letter on May 7 special issue notes most radical change in psychotherapy has been shift from medical-illness model to more fitness-based model

block.p: As a psychotherapist in practice for more than 30 years, I was very pleased to see so much space devoted to the subject of emotions in your magazine. The most radical change I have seen in therapy is a shift from the medical-illness model for common emotional problems to a more ''fitness based'' model. Most patients are simply in bad emotional shape.

As a psychotherapist in practice for more than 30 years, I was very pleased to see so much space devoted to the subject of emotions in your magazine. The most radical change I have seen in therapy is a shift from the medical-illness model for common emotional problems to a more ''fitness based'' model. Most patients are simply in bad emotional shape.

In addition to exploring the source of problems and providing a safe, supportive environment, therapists are using role-playing and visualization exercises as well as instructing clients to practice self-supportive thoughts, all of which they can also do as homework (emotional workouts). I see the future of psychotherapy as the development of these emotional-fitness regimens.
